definition: to hold/to embrace/to wrap around/to gather around (sb)/to throng/to swarm/to support/Taiwan pr. [yong3]

sentences.english: In 2015, nearly 400,000 oversea students swarmed into the Chinese market.
sentences.chinese: 2015年，近40萬國際學生蜂擁來到中國市場。

sentences.english: They came to town in swarms.
When the bell rang, the pupils ran helter-skelter out of the door.
sentences.chinese: 下課鈴響時，學生們蜂擁衝出門去。

sentences.english: People crowded to see the match.
sentences.chinese: 人們蜂擁而來觀看比賽。

sentences.english: The Maltese are used to strange visitors invading their homeland.
sentences.chinese: 馬耳他人已經習慣了陌生遊客的蜂擁而至。

sentences.english: People and mail flooded in, mostly complaining about the government.
sentences.chinese: 人羣和郵件蜂擁而來，大多是爲了表達對政府的不滿。

sentences.english: Once detected, the wearers are swarmed.
sentences.chinese: 一旦檢測到，配戴者都蜂擁。

sentences.english: Everybody was like squishing; pushing and kicking together get in line.
sentences.chinese: 大家又擠又推又踢的蜂擁而上。

sentences.english: As soon as the train pulled in, all the passengers rushed to get seats.
sentences.chinese: 火車一到，乘客們蜂擁而上搶座位。

sentences.english: The swarming ranks press on and on, the dense brigades press on.
sentences.chinese: 蜂擁隊列紛紛壓陣，重旅應先行。

sentences.english: From London to Tokyo, crowds have flocked to see this musical extravaganza.
sentences.chinese: 從倫敦到東京各地，觀衆蜂擁而來觀賞這場音樂盛宴。

sentences.english: So the stampede to the Adirondacks began.
sentences.chinese: 所以人們開始蜂擁到阿迪朗達山脈。

sentences.english: Some 30, 000 people have jammed Cairo’s most famous square.
sentences.chinese: 約三萬民衆蜂擁至開羅最著名廣場。

sentences.english: From near and far reporters streamed to interview Rontgen .
sentences.chinese: 遠近四方的記者蜂擁而至，採訪倫琴。

sentences.english: A stampede broke out when the doors opened.

definition: lit. hiding the sky and covering the earth (idiom); fig. earth-shattering/omnipresent/of universal importance
to buy frenetically/to snap up (bargains, dwindling supplies etc)
to surge up/to rise/(of tensions etc) to run high
pincer attack/attack from two or more sides/converging attack/attack on a flank/fork in chess, with one piece making two attacks
the tide rises, the boat floats (idiom); fig. to change with the overall trend/to develop according to the situation
to rush like ducks (idiom); the mob scrabbles madly for sth unobtainable/an unruly crowd on a wild goose chase
to form a long queue (idiom)/(of cars) to be bumper to bumper
